user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_dma_map:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_dma_map(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				 int nents_in,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i, j;
	void *vaddr_sg_lo, *vaddr_sg_hi, *vaddr_lo, *vaddr_hi;
	struct metal_io_region *io;

	(void)lbus;
	(void)dir;

	/* Check if the the input virt address is MMIO address */
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		vaddr_sg_lo = sg_in[i].virt;
		vaddr_sg_hi = vaddr_sg_lo + sg_in[i].len;
		for (j = 0, io = ldev->device.regions;
		     j < (int)ldev->device.num_regions; j++, io++) {
			vaddr_lo = io->virt;
			vaddr_hi = vaddr_lo + io->size;
			if (vaddr_sg_lo >= vaddr_lo &&
			    vaddr_sg_hi <= vaddr_hi) {
				break;
			}
		}
		if (j == (int)ldev->device.num_regions) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "%s,%s: input address isn't MMIO addr: 0x%x,%d.\n",
			__func__, ldev->dev_name, vaddr_sg_lo, sg_in[i].len);
			return -EINVAL;
		}
	}
	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_dma_map:
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
...
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
					 of each of the pages in the I/O
					 region */
	size_t			 size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
					 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
for (j = 0, io = ldev->device.regions; j < (int)ldev->device.num_regions; j++, io++) {

static int metal_uio_dev_dma_map(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				 int nents_in,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_out)
explanation:
I selected fragments that show non-const pointer types used in a read-only fashion (function parameters that are only read, local pointers used only for comparisons/reads, struct members declared as void* used as read-only addresses) and the memcpy that reads from sg_in. These are the places most likely to require const qualification under MISRA C: pointers that could be declared to point to const-qualified types.

Other parts of the function were not included because they do not relate to pointer const-qualification or are clearly destinations/written-to and therefore should not be const:
- sg_out is used as the destination of memcpy (written to) and thus should remain a non-const pointer; it is intentionally not const.
- The integer loop counters and scalar parameters (i, j, nents_in, dir) are non-pointer types and not subject to Rule 8.13.
- The (void)lbus and (void)dir lines simply mark unused parameters and do not themselves indicate const qualification issues beyond the function signature already reported.
- Logging, comparisons, loop control and return statements do not affect pointer constness and so were not flagged.

I focused on all places where pointers to object data that appear only to be read are declared or used (parameters, local temporary pointers, and struct members that hold virtual addresses). Those are the relevant fragments that should be investigated for possible const qualification.
